questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth has a triangular garden with sides of 3, 4, and 5 paws. What is the perimeter?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 3 + 4 + 5 = 12 paws. A perfectly measured triangle, as expected from Sir Whiskersworth!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington's circular tea table has a radius of 4 paws. What is the diameter?
questions.explanation: Diameter = 2 √ó radius = 2 √ó 4 = 8 paws. A perfectly round table for elegant tea service!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson's square investigation board has sides of 6 paws each. What is the area?
questions.explanation: Area = side √ó side = 6 √ó 6 = 36 square paws. Plenty of space for all those clues!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles has a rectangular study with length 8 paws and width 5 paws. What is the area?
questions.explanation: Area = length √ó width = 8 √ó 5 = 40 square paws. A spacious study for mathematical contemplation!

questions.question: A cat's circular scratching post has a circumference of 18.84 paws. What is the radius? (Use œÄ ‚âà 3.14)
questions.explanation: Circumference = 2œÄr, so r = 18.84 √∑ (2 √ó 3.14) = 3 paws. A perfectly sized scratching post!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth has a rectangular flower bed that is 10 paws long and 7 paws wide. What is the perimeter?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 2 √ó (length + width) = 2 √ó (10 + 7) = 34 paws. A well-bordered flower bed!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington's triangular bookshelf has sides of 5, 12, and 13 paws. What is the perimeter?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 5 + 12 + 13 = 30 paws. A perfectly triangular bookshelf!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson has a square evidence board with an area of 49 square paws. What is the length of each side?
questions.explanation: Area = side¬≤, so side = ‚àö49 = 7 paws. A perfectly square evidence board!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles has a circular tea tray with a diameter of 12 paws. What is the radius?
questions.explanation: Radius = diameter √∑ 2 = 12 √∑ 2 = 6 paws. A perfectly round tea tray!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth is building a rectangular fence. The length is 15 paws and the width is 8 paws. What is the area enclosed?
questions.explanation: Area = length √ó width = 15 √ó 8 = 120 square paws. A spacious fenced area!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington has a triangular garden plot with base 6 paws and height 8 paws. What is the area?
questions.explanation: Area = (base √ó height) √∑ 2 = (6 √ó 8) √∑ 2 = 24 square paws. A perfectly triangular garden!

questions.question: Inspector Clawson's circular magnifying glass has a radius of 3 paws. What is the area? (Use œÄ ‚âà 3.14)
questions.explanation: Area = œÄr¬≤ = 3.14 √ó 3¬≤ = 28.26 square paws. A perfectly round magnifying glass!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles has a square study desk with sides of 9 paws each. What is the perimeter?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 4 √ó side = 4 √ó 9 = 36 paws. A perfectly square study desk!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth is measuring a rectangular pond. The length is 12 paws and the width is 5 paws. What is the perimeter?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 2 √ó (length + width) = 2 √ó (12 + 5) = 34 paws. A well-measured pond!

questions.question: Lady Pawsington has a circular tea cup with a circumference of 25.12 paws. What is the diameter? (Use œÄ ‚âà 3.14)
questions.explanation: Circumference = œÄd, so d = 25.12 √∑ 3.14 = 8 paws. A perfectly round tea cup!

questions.question: Professor Tinkles has a rectangular study with length 10 paws and width 6 paws. What is the area?
questions.explanation: Area = length √ó width = 10 √ó 6 = 60 square paws. A spacious study for mathematical contemplation!

questions.question: Sir Whiskersworth has a triangular garden with sides of 5, 12, and 13 paws. What is the perimeter?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 5 + 12 + 13 = 30 paws. A perfectly measured triangle, as expected from Sir Whiskersworth!

questions.explanation: Area = (base √ó height) √∑ 2 = (8 √ó 6) √∑ 2 = 24 square paws. A perfectly triangular flower bed!
